p.s: As stated in the summary the speech by Barack Obama is about the importance of intercultural understanding and student exchanges.

In the following I will analyse the structure of the text, the line of argumentation and the stylistic devices the author uses in order to convince the reader with his/her opinion of going on an exchange to help the world getting connected.
The speech is an excerpt and does not really have paragraphs.
Furthermore it's divided in two themes which Obama trystries to connect in his speech.

On the one hand it deals with ObamasObama's own experiences from his visit to Istanbul, where he hosted a students' roundtable at the Culture and Arts Center of Mimar Sinan Fine Art University in Tophane, and on the other it's about how he uses these experiences to let them have an effect for the whole world.

When he first talks about his trip to Turkey in cause of him being committed to rebuild a relationship between the United States and the people of the Muslim world, it's clear to see that Obama is a very familiar man, who wants the whole world to be connected (l. 1-2).

To him it seems important that every teenager knows how to handle to bring the foreign countries together and that young, passionated, engaged people who are deeply informed about the world around them should use their gift to make effort possible (l. 6-8).

In addition to that it's important to mention that Barack Obama is a Presidentpresident and introduces himself to his environment with the goal of reaching most people as possible with his message (l. 4).

So his new ways to connect young Americans to young people all around the world are supporting opportunities to learn new lenguageslanguages, and serve and study, welcoming students from other countries (l. 9-11).
Since this has always been a critical part of how America engages the world he wants to mention simple exchanges (l. 11-13).
To emphasize the actual point he uses the metaphor simple exchanges can break down walls between us in line 13.
People should simply come together and share experiences or just talk to each other.

By mentioning that in our lifeslives we all joined together by our pursuit of a productive and purposeful life he makes the reader feel like they're also part of the whole theme and that we all belong together in any type of way (l. 14-17).
Progress starts with any of us (l. 17).
He brings the reader into the speech and talks to everyone of us with saying: To all of you (l. 18) and suggests us to wetherwhether choose longstanding divisions or lasting peace.
He mentions that building new bridges instead of building new walls can be so easy if only you get involved with this endeavor.
All in all the metaphors in the text help to underline the mainpointsmain points and make the reader think about the theme again.
And that's also what Barack wants to reach with his speech.
